text:
Yeah, Michael said
most of my work is in health behavior
change and helping people with changing their lifestyle
habits, physical activity,

weight management,
and things of that. And so I often talk to
behavioral scientists and work on what they call just in
time adaptive interventions,

or trying to think about
how to make interventions be more timely and do the right
thing in the right places. But since this is
an HI seminar, I

want to tell you a
little bit about some of the thinking you've
been doing recently about how design changes, how
well these interventions work.

And so just to set the stage,
I'm going to start with a quote from one of my
colleagues, who is

a very senior behavioral
scientist, who has been developing--
so she was one of the leaders in early digital
interventions for weight

management. And this is actually a
very, very smart person. But I think this represents how
a lot of people from the health

sciences and the
behavioral sciences think about interventions. And so basically
what she says is

that she's been doing
this for a long time. And whether she used old school
Palm Pilots, or Android phones,

or iPhones, or
whatever it is, as long as she puts the same, the right
ingredients into these things,

her weight loss interventions
pretty much work equivalently. It doesn't matter how
beautiful they are.

It doesn't matter how well
they're designed they are. And really the
assumption here is that really what
matters are these things

that behavioral scientists
refer to as behavioral change techniques, which
are basically, you

can think of them as the active
ingredients of how mobile health interventions and other
digital interventions work,

which are the things that you
are asking the person to do. Whether you are asking
them to set goals,

whether you're sending
them a reminder, whether you're asking
them to plan things. And there's an
extensive literature

that has basically summarized
the behavioral science work over the last
70 or 80 years

that has basically extracted
these various operations that we're referring to as
behavioral change techniques

from that literature, to say
these are the-- and these are the things that we need
to be asking people

to do in order to help
them change their behavior. And a lot of the evidence
in behavioral science,

think about systematic reviews
and meta analyses really deal with trying to
get evidence for which

of these various
behavioral change techniques are effective,
for what kind of conditions and for what populations.

But the assumption
here is that if you do the right things, if
you're actually-- that things

are going to work pretty well. As long as the design
is reasonably usable, you don't have to worry
too much about design.

But we all know the design
actually does matter. That often how you
design these things

can make a big
difference in terms of how people experience them
and even how effective they are. I'll give you some
examples of that.

So what I want to do for
the next 40 minutes or so is give you some
sense of how we can

think about this issue in a
little bit more robust way. And so to put some flesh
on this notion that sometimes design matters and
how to think about when it does.

And so I first got interested
in this almost 20 years ago. When I was a PhD student,
I had the good luck

to work with James
Landay, who is now here, and Sunny Consolvo,
who is at Google, owns one of Sunny's
early projects

called UbiFit, which is
one of the early smartphone interventions for
physical activity. And what Sunny did
with these things,

and we were using Windows
mobile phones at the time, and she developed this
little garden display that sat on the lock
screen of the phone,

that basically gave
people feedback on how active they've been
over the course of the week and whether they've accomplished
their physical activity goals.

And inside, there was an app
that did the same stuff where you could log the
activity, and also

a sensor that was used
as part of the system, would automatically track
some of these activities. But Sunny wanted to know whether
having this kind of a garden

display in addition to
the app would actually make a difference. So she ran a study,
where we basically

saw that when people had a
version of this application that had a garden display, the
trajectory of physical activity

over time was different
than for people who had the exact same
application and the sensor, but without the garden display.

In the latter case, people
would took a decay over time. Well, if people had
the garden display that they would stay flat.

And the question is, why,
why was this difference here? And if you think about this
from the perspective of behavior

change techniques,
a lot of things about these two versions
of the application were exactly the same.

So what the thing did
was pretty much the same. It provided feedback on
behavior and goal progress.

It allowed people
to self-monitor. And it allowed
people to set goals. So you couldn't do anything
more with the garden display

version of the app than
you could do without it. But one actually worked
better than the other. And so when we started
thinking about it,

really that the key thing
here that we came up with is that not having to go into
an app to see your progress

allowed people to
see the feedback on the physical activity
a lot more often. So basically they
would see it every time

they would pull the phone
out of their pocket. And so that frequency
of the feedback was probably what
made the difference.

We didn't have any data to
actually say that that's exactly what happened. But I started
thinking about what

makes a particular instantiation
of a behavior change technique different. Yeah, of course.

I'm not a behavioral scientist. Would they say that is actually
a different behavior change?

I'll come to that in a second. But my sense is
for this it's not. And I'll tell you-- I'll explain it in
a couple of minutes

why I think it's different. But that frequency was probably
what matters is really what

came from the qualitative data. So when we interview
people, they would say, every time I would
look at the phone,

I would see this feedback,
and that was really great. But I'll come back to Michael's
question in just a second

because I think part of
what we need to really be thoughtful about is when is
something a different behavior

change technique versus
a different design of the same thing. And I have some thoughts
about how that works. And then I get to Michigan, and
I started teaching this class.

I developed this class
called SI 684, which is about design of consumer
health technologies.

And this is kind
of a funky class. So what I'm asking the students
to do for big chunk of the class is read papers in
psychology, write papers

on different kinds, different
theories, and different kinds of behavior change techniques. And then we think about
how you can implement

those very theories in
digital interventions, and what the trade-offs of
different designs might be.

So we might have a week
that looks at goal setting. And they would read all
of the foundational papers

in goal setting, like Locke and
Latham's American Psychologist review article. And learn things like this,
that the goal setting tends

to skew the effectiveness
of goal setting tends to scale
with the difficulty of the goals, that
self-efficacy moderates

how well goal setting works, the
commitment is a big motivator, and so on. But when you actually
start to design for this,

it turns out there are a
whole bunch of other questions that you have to make
some decisions on. Where in the interface are
you going to put goal setting?
How many goals to set? What kind of time frame to use? Should you use daily goals. Should you use weekly goals?

Is there a hierarchy
of goals, and so on? And the question becomes,
which of these questions actually matter?

And which of these
design decisions actually don't matter very much. And so I think a key thing
that we as a design field,

need to be thinking about is,
can we think about the role that design plays in
these interventions

in a principled way? And over the last few years-- and what I want
to tell you now is

how I've been starting
to think about this. And a key part of this
is to really think about these interventions
in a causal way.

So we've taken a directed
acyclic graph, which many of you are familiar with.

And we created this
adaptation of them that we're causing
causal pathway diagrams. They basically try to be
explicit about the role

that various nodes play in
how an intervention works. And so we distinguish
between preconditions,

which are the things you can
think of it as light switches, that if a precondition
is not present, the whole causal
chain breaks down.

We distinguish between
moderators, which increase or decrease the effectiveness
of a particular intervention.

And then what you have
in the stem, which is the middle line
that goes horizontally, is a set of outcomes
that you would expect,

if the intervention is working
how you intend it to work. So what are the
proximal outcomes that might show up first, and
then how this leads to the more

distal health outcomes and
implementation outcomes that you care about. In this case, this is just a
reminder within a medical record

to help clinicians develop
a screen for depression

on a regular basis. And one of the big
barriers in doing this is that clinicians
are overwhelmed.

They have a very short visit. They're trying to do a bunch
of stuff at the same time, talk to the patient, charts,
do all of these things.

And so we think that's
such a divided attention is a big barrier here. And so the reason that
a reminder might work

is because it brings-- increases the salience
of the need to screen. So you can even think
about these causal diagrams

they're giving you. Without ever deploying
anything, some basic way of gauging plausibility, whether
a particular intervention is

a good match for the problem
that you're trying to solve. But what does this all
have to do with the design?

So what it has to
do with the design is that I'm
increasingly thinking that the design matters.

What it differentially
changes how particular set of moderators or
preconditions for intervention

are actually activated. And so if you have-- and this
now gets to your question,

Michael, if what
you're doing creates a new stem for a diagram, if you
have a different intervention.

But if the change in
the design is only messing with the stuff
that is up and down, if with the preconditions
and moderators,

You can think of it as basically
the design is changing these--

affect modifiers on
the intervention. And I think a lot of the
things when the design ends up

mattering is that it
does that differentially. And, of course,
you can have things

that do both of these things. And I'll give you a couple
of examples of that as well. But really the way
that I'm thinking

about when design matters
is when it actually changes these things that
modify how an intervention works

in terms of the causal process
through which that intervention is working. So let me give
you a few examples

of what that might look like. So one of them is early on we
developed this mobile health interventions for physical
activity called HeartSteps.

And for the purposes of
our discussion, I mean, it was intended initially
for sedentary individuals.

We have customized it for
cardiovascular disease prevention. But in the first version
of this intervention,

we had two what we're calling
push intervention, basically things that we send to people
via push notifications.

One of them were
basically loop prompts asking people to be active.

And I'll tell you a little
bit more about them. And the other one is
a prompt asking people to make a plan of how
they're going to be

active on the following day. And both of these
are theory-based. And so activity
suggestions you can think of as being
cues to action there.

And what we try to do is
make these things really, really actionable. So we would use the location
data and the weather data

and the time of the day to
customize what kind of message we would send to a person. And so to make sure that
what we're sending to people

was appropriate for their
current circumstances, to make it more likely that they
would be able to do something

with that in the near term. And we had two versions
of these things.

One of them were just
asking basically people to go for a short walk. Think about roughly 1,000 steps
or 10 minutes or so walking.

And the idea was that if
you do a few of these things over the course of the
day, that should increase your physical activity.

But they're also just so many
ways you can ask people to walk. You run out of options
pretty quickly.

So we had this second bank of
messages that are basically just asking people to move
around a little bit, to disrupt

sedentary time. So we would ask them to
dance while cooking or look at the clock and do
squats or whatever

it is because they could be
a little bit more engaging. So this was-- we
originally developed this little second
bank of messages purely

to help with the engagement,
to make them funny, to make them-- to
make them cute.

And both of these were
basically sent in the same way. And I'll show you
that in a second.

The other option, the other
intervention component was planning. And this is a version of what
in psychology is referred

to as implementation
intentions, which is basically a form of planning where you're
very specific about when, where,

and how you're going
to do something. And what we did is
basically-- again, thinking about engagement,
the way that if you run

an experiment and
implementation of intentions in social psychology, you
bring people to a lab,

you give them a piece
of paper, and you ask them to write a
plan for something, when they're going to do their
math homework over the holiday

break. And so people write
down the plan. So the digital version of that
is basically just a text box.

Basically, this is a
high fidelity version of how implementation
intentions are typically used.

But we also know that most of
our lives are pretty routinized. We do same stuff time and
time and time and again.

And so in order to
decrease burden, especially since we were initially focusing
on older people, people who

don't particularly like to type
on the phone and we figured, if they make a plan, we'll just
make that plan available to them

in the future so
some of the time, they can just pick a
plan that they already made that might be
appropriate for the next day.

And so, again, we
had these two forms of planning where we
were originally just

thinking it would be-- the second version would just
be used to reduce burden.

And if it works
just as well, you can just use that
instead of having people have to write a
plan at the same time.

And then we ran a study
to try to actually look at these two components. And for those of you who are not
familiar with micro randomized

trials, this is a new
experimental design that my colleague Susan Murphy
developed about 10 years ago,

which basically is intended
to help you get a signal on whether a particular part of
a digital health intervention

is doing what it's supposed
to do in the short term. And so the way that this
works is that every time you

have a chance to provide
a particular intervention, let's say you want
to send someone

a reminder for to take their
hypertension medication, which happens once a day. So you have what is called
the decision point, which

is once a day at the time when
the reminder might be sent. And then let's say you
have an instrument,

it's a pill bottle
that can record whether someone took a reminder
or the medication or not.

And so with the
randomized trial, if you want to see whether
reminders help, every single day

for every person
in the study, you would randomize whether you
send the reminder or not. And for each after each one
of those randomizations,

you would collect your what is
called the proximal outcome, the near term outcome,
which is, in this case, whether they took the pill.

And then you can
basically analyze do people take pills
more when you send them

a reminder versus not. But also since you have a
randomization over time-- it's a sequential
randomization--

you can start doing analysis
like does it matter-- what the weather is like outside
when the reminder comes or does

it matter if the people
are at home or at work. You can actually look
at contextual moderation of these things, which
is pretty interesting.

Why is it interesting? Because it helps
you make decisions about how you should optimally
provide these interventions.

And so we did this with
both of these components. So in the case of
activity suggestions,

we had five decision
points a day. So five times a
day, we had the time when we might be able to send
someone an activity suggestion.

And what we did is, for
each person in the study, we randomized each one of those
five points every day, one,

whether we send them
a suggestion or not. And then if we randomize them
to send them a suggestion, whether we would send them
a walking suggestion or one

of these little
antecedent suggestions. And then we looked at how much
they moved over the 30 minutes

after that randomization. That was our proximal outcome. And then we did something
similar for planning as well,

where basically
every night, we would randomize whether we would ask a
person to plan for the next day.

And then when we did
ask them to plan, we would randomize whether to
write a new plan or we would

give them a list of the
previously made plans that they could just
choose from one. And in this case,
our proximal outcome was the step count
on the next day.

And the idea is that
basically, if you plan a large amount of
activity for the next day, that should get reflected in how
much you walk on the next day.

So let me talk about what
we saw in planning first. And so if you combine
both classes of planning,

both types of interfaces, and
you compare them to no planning, there's not much going on. But if you actually
start separating them,

you start seeing a signal. So when people were asked to
do an open to write a new plan,

they ended up with about 400
or 500 steps more per day than when they didn't plan. And this was starting to get
marginally significant and given

the small sample size. But then when you actually
start taking moderation into account, the
time of moderation

by contextual factors,
basically, our participants did not like
planning on weekends. And nothing worked on weekends.

But on weekdays,
an open-ended plan provided an almost 900 steps
over not planning at all,

while the other interface
didn't do squat, no effect on not planning.

And what's also interesting--
and this is actually relatively rare for mobile
health interventions-- is that when the
open planning worked,

that effect stayed
constant over time. It didn't actually
degrade over time. And you'll see in a second
why I'm pointing that out.

So open-ended planning worked,
but picking from a list didn't.

And the question becomes why. And so here is where this is
really a design variation.

We have two-- yeah.  Did it continue to micro
randomize over the six weeks?

Yeah, we micro randomize
every single day over the six weeks for everyone. And do you feel--
have you, for example,

looked at streaks where,
just by random chance, they were getting assigned
to the planning for five

days in a row? Right. We didn't look at
streaks for planning, but we did for the
other intervention.

And I'll show you some data
about that, because actually, this moderation by dose ends
up being pretty interesting.

Yeah. I ask because in some
of the previous work we had done on outside of health
and more time spent on like,

Netflix and so on, it was
not the intervention so much as it was the rotation, the
change of intervention that

prevented the banner blindness. That was actually the
thing that was the-- Yeah. And we actually got
something very similar

to that for the
activity suggestions that I'll show you
in a little bit. I can take a look at
the data on planning.

That would actually
be pretty interesting. But I mean, with all of
these results, really, you're marginalizing over
those variations in sequences.

And we're still seeing
these effects with that. But the question is like,
why does this version work

and the other one doesn't. So this is how psychologists
think about implementation intentions. This is the causal diagram,
a simple causal diagram

of implementation intentions. This is Peter Switzer
and Pascal Sheeran that have done a lot
of work in this space.

And really, the
key mechanism here is that when you create this
kind of a really specific plan,

what happens is that
there is encoding of the link between the context
in which the action should take

place and the action itself. And they've done
some MRI studies that actually are collecting
neurophysiological data

about this. And then when you encounter
the context in which that you're supposed
to do this action,

basically your brain can
just trigger the action without the need for
further deliberation. And this is why implementation
intentions are actually

pretty powerful is because
they remove this need to make a decision again,
do I want to do this.

But basically, the action can
just be triggered automatically when you encounter the context.

And clearly,
encountering the context is a precondition
for this to happen. If you don't encounter the
context, nothing happens.

And there's a fair bit work on
some of the other moderators, like conflicting goals. If you have a strong conflicting
goal with the action,

then that can derail how
implementation intentions work or not. But it turns out there is
another really important

precondition, which is that
for the actual planning to do this kind of
encoding, you need

some attention during the
actual process of planning. And this we think
is what was going

on with this difference
between the open-ended planning and the planning that was
picking from the list.

If we look at the log
data, it takes people about a second to move
through the screen

where they pick from a list. And it takes them
substantially longer. It was something
like 7.5 seconds

to do a very quick plan in-- and so this added friction of
having to write a plan we think

is actually enforcing a
certain amount of attention to the process of
planning, which is actually

necessary to make this kind
of neural encoding take place. And so what the interface
is doing in this case

is actually forcing this
important precondition. And so what we ended up
doing for future versions

of HeartSteps is creating a form
that you're still [INAUDIBLE]. And so you can now
start thinking about,

can do systematic research, how
much attention is needed here, and what kind of interfaces are
still usable and relatively low

burden, while still engaging
enough attention for that encoding to take place.

And so in this
particular case, it hit a really important
precondition.

So let's talk about
activity suggestions because this is
really funky as well. So again, all of these things
were provided in the same way.

We would randomize
people five times a day. And then when they
were sent the message, they would just get
a text notification

with the content of the message. And here too, we actually see
that these two types of messages

did not work the same way. And in particular,
walking suggestions did result in some
increase in steps.

But these anti-sedentary
suggestions didn't, even though
people really liked them. When we interview
them, they say,

oh, these were a lot
more fun, but they didn't seem to do anything,
at least initially, when we started looking at the data.

The other thing
that was interesting is that the walking working
suggestions work pretty well at the start of the study.

So at the start of the study,
they added 271 studies. That's only in the 30 minutes
following the randomization.

That's actually a fair
bit for 30 minutes. But then what we saw is
that with every passing day,

that effect would go down. And by the end, by
about three weeks in, they stopped doing
anything at all.

And so now we're
thinking about why, why is this effect going down.

And one easy hypothesis
is that it's habituation.

What is habituation? Think of habituation as
the decrease in response--

and this concept comes
out of early psychology, the early 20th century
for psychology. It's having to do with reflexes.

If you go to a doctor to
test your knee reflexes and they hit you with
a hammer, initially,

your knee will pop up. But if they keep hitting it,
over time, that reflects stops

and you stop getting a response
until the reflex recovers. And we see this kind of
dynamic often probably

for those of you who get
a lot of notifications, probably you see this
thing with notifications. The more notifications
you get, the less likely

you are actually look
at the notification because you just get
inundated with them. And so we thought maybe
this is what's going on.

In which case, it's
really not the time. But to your point, it's
actually the frequency of how much we're
bothering people. So I'll spare you
of the gory details

of actually the analysis. But what we started
doing is looking at how these
messages are modified

by the dose, how many
messages people receive over the last few days across
both types of interventions.

And what we found was
actually pretty interesting. And so what this big
regression table is saying

is that we are actually
seeing two different patterns of responding.

So for walking suggestions,
there is this initial impact.

And that impact
continues to fall down by the day in the study. So it's purely time-based thing.

But for anti-sedentary
suggestions, when we started doing
moderation by dose, we actually get the main effect.

We actually get the effect
of antecedent suggestions. But that effect
decreases by how many

previous messages someone has
received over the last few days. And we've done this
analysis for the three days and five days and seven days.

We get basically exactly
the same results. So how many messages
someone gets

seems to modify the impact
of anti-sedentary suggestion, but not walking suggestion.

And the question is like,
why is this the case. It's not engagement
because we know

that the planning stage is
effective over the course of the whole study. So here's one
hypothesis-- so you

can think about these cues to
action as working through--

and this is a riff on
theory of planned behavior. But basically, the intention
to follow the suggestion being

due to two big influences. One of it is what often is
referred to is attitude,

how valuable do you think this
thing is and what shaping that. And that attitude can take a
hit from the burden of what

you're asking someone to do. And then the other
one is called-- you can think of it as
self-efficacy or perceived

behavioral control. It's like, are you
actually able to do this. So for what we think is
going on for anti-sedentary

suggestions is that the
main burden is actually coming just from the annoyances
of receiving messages.

But people are getting
a fair bit of value from just the engagement
that these are kind of funny

and engaging. So the value is coming
from engagement. But most of what is
driving the burden,

which would be the
reducing the attitude, is really coming
from the frequency. Well, for walking
suggestions, the most value

is coming from the fact
that these are actually pretty actionable. And people will tell us this
in interviews where they really

liked when they got something
that was really well tuned to their current context, but
it's a more effortful thing.

It's you asking people
to go for a walk. So there is a burden that
comes from the effort. But also what we
think is going on

is that the value of
taking a short walk started reducing over time. So this is behavioral
economic hypothesis

that just how people think
about the value of taking a very short walk, that is
getting reduced over time.

So the mechanisms are
working slightly differently for these two things. Even though the
content is presented

in exactly the same way, it's
just that the ask of the user, is it just to move around for a
little bit or to go for a walk,

is different across these
two, in which case, it's activating different parts
of this causal pathway.

That's a hypothesis. You can, again, run a
whole bunch of studies that you can then try to get
more detailed evidence for this.

But that might explain
why this is going on.

Let me give you
one last example. And this is from a intervention
that my PhD student [INAUDIBLE]

has been working on over
the last couple of years. And so it's really
interested in helping people

to enjoy physical activity more. And so they develop this
system called Walk2Joy which is intended
to basically improve

what they refer to as
affective associations with physical activity. Think about your
affective associations

as being two things. One, so you can think
of it as gut reactions to the thought of something.

So if you were bullied in school
during gym class and someone

immediately gets triggered. Those are affective evaluations. Affective attitudes
are basically

more recent versions of that. So you say, I don't like running
or I'm not the kind of person who does x, y, and z.

And so the idea
was like-- so she wanted to know whether can
we actually change these because there's some pretty
good literature over the last 10

years that has shown that people
who have positive affective associations with
physical activity

are able to maintain
it much longer. So this is all around
how do we actually support people over the
long periods of time

in being able to be active. And so what we did
is actually-- so she developed three intervention
components for this.

And we basically ran a study. And this is a factorial
experiment study where for each one of those
three components--

I'll show you those
in just a second-- we, at baseline,
randomized each person whether they would get each
one of those components.

So basically, you can
think of it as a 2 to the n-th experimental design. So if you have three
components, each one of them

can be either on or off. Each person gets
randomized to one of eight cells, one of
the unique combinations

of those three components. People had Fitbits so we could
track their physical activity.

And we did this,
again, for six weeks. We want to be
[INAUDIBLE] baseline. And what we wanted to for
the package as a whole

is do we get a change in
these effective associations. But we also looked at
some of the other data, including steps and
effective evaluations.

So the first one of
these things that we randomized that these little--

basically, you can think of
them activity suggestions. But they have these
little cute animal GIFs that were intended
to make people smile.

And she had a whole
library of these things. Waddling penguins and bear
pushing against the tree

Hopefully, this is going

activity more positive.
